In the BC Paradox, the issue arises from the confirmation of a universal hypothesis through equivalent conditions that can lead to intuitive contradictions. According to the proposed hypothesis "All swans are white" (∀x(S(x)→W(x))), seeing a white swan (S(a) ∧ W(a)) confirms the hypothesis, but seeing a non-swan that is white (¬S(b) ∧ W(b))—which should not logically affect the hypothesis—also confirms it under the equivalence of ∀x(S(x)→W(x)) to ∀x(¬W(x)→¬S(x)). This creates a paradoxical situation in confirmation standards, reflecting the description of the BC Paradox.
